column1: Art Institute of Chicago////The most vivid example is 'Hinoki'.  At first glance
column2: it appears to be a gigantic debarked tree trunk.  Instead
column3: it's a carved and assembled replica of a fallen oak tree.  The original was cut into pieces then transported to a  studio.  Fiberglass molds were made from the pieces.  Those were then shipped to Japan and expert carvers spent years carving a replica in cypress.  (Hinoki is the Japanese word for cypress.)  The pieces were then assembled to produce the gallery-filling work on display.
